title: Tailor Your Dress: Bigger, Smaller, or Tighter — The Easy Beginner's Guide

steps.title: In general, you can alter a dress 1 to 2 sizes.
steps.content: In general, you can alter a dress 1 to 2 sizes. It’s usually easier to make a dress smaller than it is to make one larger, but both can be done. If you need your dress tailored more than a few sizes, it’s probably best to bring it to a professional. [1] X Research source Dresses made out of cotton and linen are very easy to tailor, while chiffon, organza, and jersey fabrics can be harder to work with. Vintage clothes usually have a larger fit. So, if you're working with a vintage dress, focus your changes on making it smaller, especially on the shoulders.

steps.title: Pin the dress so it fits your body.
steps.content: Pin the dress so it fits your body. Put your dress on and hold it tightly against your body (as tight as you want it to fit at the end of your tailoring). Use sewing pins to hold the fabric in place, going from the arm hole down to the bottom hem on each side of the dress. When you’re done, carefully take the dress off without disturbing the pins. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Flip the dress inside out, then mark the inside.
steps.content: Flip the dress inside out, then mark the inside. Turn the dress inside out so you can see the seams. Grab a marker and draw a straight line down both sides of the dress following the sewing pins. When you’ve drawn your line, you can take the pins out. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Sew a straight stitch down both side seams of the dress.
steps.content: Sew a straight stitch down both side seams of the dress. Take your dress over to your sewing machine and load it with thread that matches your dress color. Use a straight stitch to sew down the lines you made on the inside of your dress. When you’re done, flip your dress right side out and try on your new snug garment! If the side seams are too bulky, use scissors to cut off the excess fabric from the inside of the dress. [4] X Research source Some dresses, like formal ones, should be opened at the seams in order to take them in with a nice finish.

steps.title: Pin your dress to see how much you need to take in.
steps.content: Pin your dress to see how much you need to take in. Put your dress on and pinch the waist on both sides to see how much you want to take in. Use safety pins to hold the fabric in place while you carefully take the dress off. [5] X Research source If you only want to take the dress in temporarily, you can pin it and just make some small stitches by hand.

steps.title: Draw a triangle shape on the inside of the waist.
steps.content: Draw a triangle shape on the inside of the waist. Turn your dress inside out and draw a triangular shape on both sides of the waist with the point facing downwards. This triangle shape is called a dart , and it will help pinch the fabric in to take in the dress. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Sew 2 darts on either side of the dress.
steps.content: Sew 2 darts on either side of the dress. With the dress still turned inside out, fold the triangle over itself so the edges line up. Pin the edges down, then sew along the lines using a straight stitch. Do this on both sides of your waist to take them in. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Rip the seams on the side of the dress.
steps.content: Rip the seams on the side of the dress. Figure out where the dress is tight on you (usually it’s the waist or the bust). Grab your seam ripper and rip out the section that’s tight on either side of the dress. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Cut out a triangular piece of fabric to fit each side.
steps.content: Cut out a triangular piece of fabric to fit each side. Spread your dress out flat and hold the seams apart from each other as far as they’ll go. Grab a piece of fabric that matches the color of your dress, then cut out a triangular section that lines up with the opening in the seams. Add about 1 in (2.5 cm) around the entire triangle for a seam allowance as you cut. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Sew the new fabric into the seams.
steps.content: Sew the new fabric into the seams. Turn the dress inside out and line the triangle up with the ripped seams. Use sewing pins to attach the triangle in place, then sew it down using a zig zag stitch. Turn your dress right side out before you put it on! [10] X Research source

steps.title: Take in your dress with safety pins.
steps.content: Take in your dress with safety pins. Turn your dress inside out and gather a small section of fabric at the front of the dress just below your bust line. Slide a safety pin into the fabric, bunching it up so it stays gathered. Close the safety pin and turn the dress right side out for an instantly form-fitting dress. [11] X Research source If the waist of your dress is too big, you can use the same bunching method on either side of your waist.

steps.title: Add a belt around your waist.
steps.content: Add a belt around your waist. It’s an easy way to show off your curves and give an old dress new life. Grab your belt and tie it around the smallest part of your waist (usually above your hips). If you don’t have a belt, use a scarf instead. [12] X Research source
